docs.245a: Political aphorisms, or, The true maxims of government displayed :
docs.245b: by way of a challenge to Dr. William Sherlock, and ten other new dissenters, and recommended as proper to be read by all Protestant Jacobites.
500a: Attributed to Harrison by Wing and NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Advertisements: [1] p. at end.

Preface signed: T.H[arrison?].", possibly as editor, since it appears from "The author's advertisement" (p. [32]) that the printer is not the author. Harrison published and perhaps compiled an enlarged version under titles "Vox populi, vox Dei: being the true maxims of government" (1709) & "The judgment of whole kingdoms and nations, concerning the rights ... of kings, and ... of the people" (1710); cf. Morgan L 105, accepting the ascription of the later version to Harrison as "the most likely", though confusing the first title with "Vox populi vox Dei; or The voice of the people, the voice of God" [1719], ascribed to Samuel Brewster the elder.

Variously ascribed to Daniel Defoe by Halkett & Laing (but not by Moore); to Charles Povey by the DNB, confusingly citing the subtitle of "The judgment of whole kingdoms and nations" (1710), which is not Povey's (cf. F. B. Relton, An account of the fire insurance companies (1893), p. 463); & to John Dunton & John, lord Somers. "The doctrine of passive obedience and jure divino disproved", advertised on p. [32] as by the same author, is wrongly ascribed in Halkett & Laing to George Hickes, apparently by some confusion with a reply, "The doctrine of passive obedience ... disproved ... answered and refuted", published by Randall Taylor in 1689.
Many sentences are plagiarized without acknowledgement from Locke's second treatise of government; cf. the paragraph on p. 2-3 with Locke's Two treatises [1689], II, secs. 4, 13 & 127.

docs.245c: e codice ms. in bibliotheca Harleiana descripsit, et nunc primus edidit Thomas Hearnius; accesserunt alia.
500a: Benedict apparently had nothing to do with the authorship of the "Gesta Henrici Secundi". It was probably transcribed by his orders, together with the other manuscripts which he added to the monastic library. The real author is not known. cf. Dict. nat. biog.
Paged continuously; v. 2 has half-title only; head and tail pieces and initials; title within double lines.

The chief additions are: An account of Dr. Andrew Borde, from AthenÃ¦ oxon, v. 1, p. xxxvi-xli; The publisher's addition to the account of Dr. Borde, v. 1, p. xli-lvi; Lamentatio de morte regis Ricardi I, and De gloriosis ejus victoriis in itinere ierosolymitano [by Geoffrey de Vinsauf] v. 2, p. 748-750; An authentick evidence concerning the relick of the blood of Hales, with proper remarks upon it, by George Coningesby, v. 2, p. 751-763; The peregrination of Doctor Boarde, v. 2, p. 764-804.
"Operum nostrorum hactenus impressorum catalogus": p. 855-873.
Very rare. cf. Potthast.
